name: Shushumow
author: MyHalwad
summary: Shushumow, which also has many other names (kalkals, zinanaande), is one of the delicacies made during holidays and weddings in Somali culture! It's a fried pastry made with flour, eggs, and water (some recipes call for milk) tossed in simple sugar syrup. The dough is shaped into small balls, flattened, and curled over. It is crispy on the outside and little bit soft in the inside. Shushumow is one of my favorites.
directions: Mix flour, 1/3 cup canola oil, egg, 3 tablespoons sugar, baking powder, and salt together in the bowl of a stand mixer with an paddle attachment
Add 1/4 cup water slowly and mix until a soft dough is formed, 4 to 5 minutes
Cut dough into about thirty 1-inch pieces
Press each piece onto the back of a fork and curl it out away from you to make the shushumow
Heat 2 cups oil in a deep-fryer or large saucepan over medium heat
Fry shushumow a few at a time, stirring slowly, until golden brown, 5 to 7 minutes
Combine 1/2 cup sugar, 1/4 cup water, and cardamom in a saucepan over medium heat
Reduce heat and let simmer until sugar is dissolved, 1 to 2 minutes more
Stir in the shushumow gently until coated in the syrup
Transfer shushumow to a plate and let cool
